Package parsii.tokenizer

Class Tokenizer

java.lang.Object
parsii.tokenizer.Lookahead<Token>
parsii.tokenizer.Tokenizer
public class Tokenizer
extends Lookahead<Token>
Turns a stream of characters (Reader into a stream of Token, supporting lookahead.

Reads from the given input and parses it into a stream of tokens. By default all token types defined by Token are supported. Most of the features can be further tweaked by changing the default settings.

By default the tokenizer operates as follows:

  • Consume and ignore any whitespace characters (see Char.isWhitepace()
  • If the current character starts a line comment, read until the end of the line and ignore all characters consumed.
  • If the current character starts a block comment, read until and end of block comment is detected.
  • If the current character is a digit, parse a INTEGER, if a decimal separator is found, switch over to a DECIMAL (see Char.isDigit(). Also if the current character is a '-' and the next is a digit, we try to read a number.
  • If the current character is a letter, parse an ID (see Char.isLetter(). Once this is complete, check if the ID matches one of the supplied keywords, and convert if necessary.
  • If the current character is an opening or closing bracket, a SYMBOL for that single character is returned
  • If the current character is one of the special id starters, all valid ID characters (isIdentifierChar(Char) are consumed and returned as SPECIAL_ID
  • All other characters, especially all operators, will be read and returned as one SYMBOL. Therefore #++* will be returned as a single symbol.

    • isAtStartOfSpecialId

      protected boolean isAtStartOfSpecialId()
      Determines if the underlying input is looking at the start of a special id.

      By default this is one of the given specialIdStarters.

      Returns:
      true if the current input is the start of a special id, false otherwise

    • isAtStartOfNumber

      protected boolean isAtStartOfNumber()
      Determines if the underlying input is looking at the start of a number.

      By default this is either indicated by a digit or by '-' followed by a digit or a '.' followed by a digit.

      Returns:
      true if the current input is the start of a numeric constant, false otherwise

    • isAtBracket

      protected boolean isAtBracket​(boolean inSymbol)
      Determines if the underlying input is looking at a bracket.

      By default all supplied brackets are checked. If treatSinglePipeAsBracket is true, a single '|' is also treated as bracket.

      Parameters:
      inSymbol - determines if we're already parsing a symbol or just trying to decide what the next token is
      Returns:
      true if the current input is an opening or closing bracket

    • canConsumeThisString

      Checks if the next characters, starting from the current, match the given string.
      Parameters:
      string - the string to check
      consume - determines if the matched string should be consumed immediately
      Returns:
      true if the next characters of the input match the given string, false otherwise

    • isAtStartOfLineComment

      protected boolean isAtStartOfLineComment​(boolean consume)
      Checks if the underlying input is looking at a start of line comment.

      If a line comment is detected, any characters indicating this are consumed by this method if consume is true.

      Parameters:
      consume - determines if the matched comment start should be consumed immediately
      Returns:
      true if the next character(s) of the input start a line comment, false otherwise

      Parameters:

      Returns:

    • handleStringEscape

      protected boolean handleStringEscape​(char separator, char escapeChar, Token stringToken)
      Evaluates an string escape like \n

      The escape character is already consumed. Therefore the input points at the character to escape. This method must consume all escaped characters.

      Parameters:
      separator - the delimiter of this string constant
      escapeChar - the escape character used
      stringToken - the resulting string constant
      Returns:
      true if an escape was possible, false otherwise

    • isAtStartOfIdentifier

      protected boolean isAtStartOfIdentifier()
      Determines if the underlying input is looking at a valid character to start an identifier

      By default, only letters can start identifiers

      Returns:
      true if the underlying input is looking at a valid identifier starter, false otherwise

      Checks if the given identifier is a keyword and returns an appropriate Token
      Parameters:
      idToken - the identifier to check
      Returns:

    • isIdentifierChar

      protected boolean isIdentifierChar​(Char current)
      Determines if the given Char is a valid identifier part.

      By default, letters, digits and '_' are valid identifier parts.

      Parameters:
      current - the character to check
      Returns:
      true if the given Char is a valid identifier part, false otherwise

    • fetchSpecialId

      protected Token fetchSpecialId()
      Reads and returns a special id.
      Returns:
      the parsed special id as Token

    • fetchSymbol

      protected Token fetchSymbol()
      Reads and returns a symbol.

      A symbol are one or two characters, which don't match any other token type. In most cases, this will be operators like + or *.

      Returns:
      the parsed symbol as Token

    • isSymbolCharacter

      protected boolean isSymbolCharacter​(Char ch)
      Determines if the given Char is a symbol character.

      By default these are all non-control characters, which don't match any other class (letter, digit, whitepsace)

      Parameters:
      ch - the character to check
      Returns:
      true if the given character is a valid symbol character, false otherwise

    • fetchNumber

      protected Token fetchNumber()
      Reads and returns a number.
      Returns:
      the parsed number as Token

    • isKeywordsCaseSensitive

      public boolean isKeywordsCaseSensitive()
      Determines if keywords are case sensitive.

      By default, keywords aren't case sensitive. Therefore True and true are the same keyword.

      Returns:
      true if keywords are case sensitive, false otherwise

    • setKeywordsCaseSensitive

      public void setKeywordsCaseSensitive​(boolean keywordsCaseSensitive)
      Sets the case sensitiveness of keywords.

      This must be setup before any call to addKeyword(String) as this will determine internal data structures

      Parameters:
      keywordsCaseSensitive - true if keywords should be treated as case sensitive, false otherwise (default)

    • addKeyword

      public void addKeyword​(java.lang.String keyword)
      Adds a keyword which is now being recognized by the tokenizer

      Detection will be case insensitive. Only ID tokens (identifiers) are checked against the given keywords, therefore a keyword must be a valid identifier.

      Parameters:
      keyword - the keyword to be added to the list of known keywords.

    • addSpecialIdStarter

      public void addSpecialIdStarter​(char character)
      Adds character as a special id starter. The given character must be followed by a valid id to be recognized as SPECIAL_ID.
      Parameters:
      character - the character to be added as special id starter

    • addSpecialIdTerminator

      public void addSpecialIdTerminator​(char character)
      Adds character as a special id terminator. The given character can be placed at the end of an id to be recognized as SPECIAL_ID.
      Parameters:
      character - the character to be added as special id terminator

    • clearStringDelimiters

      public void clearStringDelimiters()
      Removes all previously registered string delimiters.

      By default " and ' are registered as string delimiters, where string enclosed by " can have characters escaped by \

    • addStringDelimiter

      public void addStringDelimiter​(char stringDelimiter, char escapeCharacter)
      Adds a new string delimiter character along with the character used to escape string within it.
      Parameters:
      stringDelimiter - the delimiter used to start and end string constants
      escapeCharacter - the character used to start an escape sequence or \0 to indicate that escaping is not supported

      Parameters:
      stringDelimiter - the delimiter used to start and end string constants

    • getDecimalSeparator

      public char getDecimalSeparator()
      Returns the decimal separator used in decimal numbers

      The default separator used is '.'

      Returns:
      the character which is detected as separator between the integer and the decimal part of a number

    • setDecimalSeparator

      public void setDecimalSeparator​(char decimalSeparator)
      Sets the character which is recognized as decimal separator.
      Parameters:
      decimalSeparator - the character to be recognized as decimal separator

    • getEffectiveDecimalSeparator

      public char getEffectiveDecimalSeparator()
      Returns the decimal separator used in the content of DECIMAL tokens.

      The default separator used is '.'. When adapting this for language dependent inputs (e.g. using ',' as decimal separator) this value should probably not be changed, as it is used in the output (content) of the Tokens and has no effect what kind of numbers are being accepted.

      Returns:
      the decimal separator used in tokens

    • setEffectiveDecimalSeparator

      public void setEffectiveDecimalSeparator​(char effectiveDecimalSeparator)
      Sets the decimal separator used in the content of DECIMAL tokens. This can differ from the character set via setDecimalSeparator(char) which is used to recognize decimal numbers. Therefore language dependent input can be parsed with a constant output being language independent.
      Parameters:
      effectiveDecimalSeparator - the character used as decimal separator in the content of decimal tokens

    • getGroupingSeparator

      public char getGroupingSeparator()
      Returns the grouping separator which can be used in numbers for group digits (e.g. in thousands).

      This character will be accepted in numbers, but ignored (not added to the content). The default value is '_'.

      Returns:
      the grouping separator accepting in numbers

    • setGroupingSeparator

      public void setGroupingSeparator​(char groupingSeparator)
      Sets the grouping separator accepting in numbers.
      Parameters:
      groupingSeparator - the character which can be used to group digits in numbers

    • getLineComment

      public java.lang.String getLineComment()
      Returns the string which starts a line comment.

      The default value is '/''/'

      Returns:
      the string sequence starting a line comment

    • setLineComment

      public void setLineComment​(java.lang.String lineComment)
      Sets the string which stats a line comment.
      Parameters:
      lineComment - the string used to detect a line comment

    • getBlockCommentStart

      public java.lang.String getBlockCommentStart()
      Returns the string which starts a block comment.

      The default value is '/''*'

      Returns:
      the string sequence starting a block comment

    • setBlockCommentStart

      public void setBlockCommentStart​(java.lang.String blockCommentStart)
      Sets the string which stats a block comment.
      Parameters:
      blockCommentStart - the string used to detect a block comment

    • getBlockCommentEnd

      public java.lang.String getBlockCommentEnd()
      Returns the string which ends a block comment.

      The default value is '*''/'

      Returns:
      the string sequence ending a block comment

    • setBlockCommentEnd

      public void setBlockCommentEnd​(java.lang.String blockCommentEnd)
      Sets the string which ends a block comment.
      Parameters:
      blockCommentEnd - the string used to detect the end of a block comment

    • more

      public boolean more()
      Boilerplate method for current().isNotEnd()
      Returns:
      true if the current token is not an "end of input" token, false otherwise.

    • atEnd

      public boolean atEnd()
      Boilerplate method for current().isEnd()
      Returns:
      true if the current token is an "end of input" token, false otherwise.

    • addError

      public void addError​(Position pos, java.lang.String message, java.lang.Object... parameters)
      Adds a parse error to the internal problem collector.

      It is preferred to collect as much errors as possible and then fail with an exception instead of failing at the first problem. Often syntax errors can be worked out by the parser and we can report a set of errors at once.

      Parameters:
      pos - the position of the error. Note that Token implements Position. Therefore the current token is often a good choice for this parameter.
      message - the message to describe the error. Can contain formatting parameters like %s or %d as defined by String.format(String, Object...)
      parameters - Contains the parameters used to format the given message

    • addWarning

      public void addWarning​(Position pos, java.lang.String message, java.lang.Object... parameters)
      Adds a warning to the internal problem collector.

      A warning indicates an anomaly which might lead to an error but still, the parser can continue to complete its work.

      Parameters:
      pos - the position of the warning. Note that Token implements Position. Therefore the current token is often a good choice for this parameter.
      message - the message to describe the earning. Can contain formatting parameters like %s or %d as defined by String.format(String, Object...)
      parameters - Contains the parameters used to format the given message

    • consumeExpectedSymbol

      public void consumeExpectedSymbol​(java.lang.String symbol)
      Consumes the current token, expecting it to be as SYMBOL with the given content
      Parameters:
      symbol - the expected trigger of the current token

    • consumeExpectedKeyword

      public void consumeExpectedKeyword​(java.lang.String keyword)
      Consumes the current token, expecting it to be as KEYWORD with the given content
      Parameters:
      keyword - the expected content of the current token

    • throwOnErrorOrWarning

      public void throwOnErrorOrWarning() throws ParseException
      Throws a ParseException if an error or warning occurred while parsing the input
      Throws:
      ParseException - if an error or warning occurred while parsing.

    • throwOnError

      public void throwOnError() throws ParseException
      Throws a ParseException if an error occurred while parsing the input.

      All warnings which occurred will be ignored.

      Throws:
      ParseException - if an error occurred while parsing.
